description:
Bacteroides pyogenes is an anaerobic, Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that is commonly found in the human gastrointestinal tract. It is a member of the Bacteroidetes phylum and is known to be an opportunistic pathogen capable of causing various infections, such as abscesses, infections of the female genital tract, and wound infections.

Bacteroides pyogenes is characterized by its ability to ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and fructose, as part of its energy-producing metabolism. It is considered an important component of the normal gut microbiome, but its overgrowth or translocation to other body sites can lead to the development of pathogenic conditions.

This species is typically sensitive to certain antibiotics, such as metronidazole and clindamycin, which are commonly used in the treatment of Bacteroides-associated infections. Understanding the ecology and pathogenic potential of Bacteroides pyogenes is important for maintaining a healthy gut microbiome and managing infections caused by this opportunistic bacterium.
